[[Falklands War]] |awards= [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] '''Sir Henry Conyers Leach''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|DL}} (18 November 1923 – 26 April 2011) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer who, as [[First Sea Lord|First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff]] during the early 1980s, was instrumental in convincing British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] that [[Falklands War|retaking the Falkland Islands from Argentina]] was feasible. On account of the determination he showed in the matter, journalist and political commentator [[Andrew Marr]] described him as Thatcher's "knight in shining gold braid".{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/military-obituaries/naval-obituaries/8474861/Admiral-of-the-Fleet-Sir-Henry-Leach.html |title=Admiral of the Fleet Sir Henry Leach |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} ==Early life== Born the third son of naval officer [[John Leach (Royal Navy officer)|John Leach]] and Evelyn Burrell Leach (née Lee), Leach was educated at [[St Peter's Court]], [[Broadstairs]], and the [[Britannia Royal Naval College|Royal Naval College, Dartmouth]]. ==Naval career== Leach joined the [[Royal Navy]] as a [[cadet]] in 1937. After the [[Second World War]] started in 1939, he served on the battleship {{HMS|Rodney|29|6}} in the South Atlantic and the cruiser {{HMS|Edinburgh|16|6}} in the Indian Ocean. Promoted to [[midshipman]] on 1 January 1941,Heathcote, p. 151 he was assigned to {{HMS|Prince of Wales|53|6}}. Before he could take up the post, however, his father was given command, so he was reassigned to {{HMS|Mauritius|80|6}}. The ''Mauritius'' soon went into refit in [[Singapore]], during which time Leach was assigned to the [[Command center|war room]] there as a plotting officer. While in Singapore, the ''Prince of Wales'' was sunk by the Japanese off Singapore, and Leach's father died in this action.Mahoney, p. 253 His obituary in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' notes that "[s]urvivors of the action remembered a forlorn midshipman searching for his father, who was among those lost. Only two nights earlier, Leach and his father had enjoyed a [[gin sling]] and a swim."{{cite web |title=The Battleships: Terror from above, Documentary |year=2001 |url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Battleships-Terror-Above-1939-Present/dp/B00005AA3F}} His next post was on the destroyer {{HMS|Sardonyx}} before being promoted to [[sub-lieutenant]] on 1 October 1942 and posted to {{HMS|Duke of York|17|6}}, the flagship of the [[Home Fleet]] in January 1943. [[File:HMS Javelin 1941 IWM FL 10524.jpg|thumb|left|The destroyer {{HMS|Javelin|F61|6}} in which Leach served as the navigating officer during the Second World War]] Leach was promoted to [[lieutenant]] in October 1943. Leach was in command of the "A" turret and he was involved in the [[Battle of the North Cape]] in December 1943. In autumn 1944, he was posted to {{HMS|Javelin|F61|6}} as the navigating officer. During his posting on ''Javelin'', a mutiny broke out whilst Leach was the duty officer: he "conducted himself well under difficult circumstances" and, after the mutiny was put down, the captain and first lieutenant were re-appointed. Leach was given the position as first lieutenant and the ship was transformed within a few weeks. In April 1946, Leach transferred to the destroyer {{HMS|Chequers||6}}. He was only at this post for a short time as he decided to gain his qualifications as a gunnery specialist at the shore establishment {{HMS|Excellent|shore establishment|6}}. After qualifying, he remained at the school as a gunnery instructor until he was posted as gunnery officer to the Second Minesweeping Flotilla in the [[Aegean Sea]]. He was promoted to [[lieutenant commander]] on 1 February 1952 and attended the [[Royal Naval College, Greenwich|Royal Naval Staff College]], before becoming a staff officer for the [[Naval Brigade]] in London for the [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|coronation of the Queen]]. In July 1953, he was posted as gunnery officer of the 5th Cruiser Squadron in {{HMS|Newcastle|C76|6}} and saw service at the end of the [[Korean War]]. He also saw service in the [[Malayan Emergency]] of 1955 when HMS ''Newcastle'' supported the Army and Royal Marines. He was promoted to [[commander]] on 30 June 1955 and served as application commander responsible for bringing the navy's first [[surface-to-air missile]], the [[Sea Slug (missile)|Sea Slug]], into service. He was then posted to the [[Admiralty]] in 1957 and was given his first command in charge of the destroyer {{HMS|Dunkirk|D09|6}} in the [[Mediterranean]] in 1959.Heathcote, p. 152. Leach was posted to the Training Directorate in the Admiralty in July 1961 and then attended the [[Joint Service Defence College]] before receiving promotion to [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]] on 31 December 1961. He became Chief Staff Officer (Plans and Operations) for the [[Eastern Fleet|Far East Fleet]] in July 1962 and organised naval support for British ground forces deployed during the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation]]. He was appointed captain of the 27th Escort Squadron, which he commanded from the ''Leander''-class frigate {{HMS|Galatea|F18|6}}, in November 1965. An appointment at the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] followed when he became Director of Naval Plans there in February 1968 before he was given another command, that of the [[aircraft carrier]] {{HMS|Albion|R07|6}}, in March 1970. Leach was a strong supporter of the abolition of the [[Rum ration|daily issue]] of [[rum]] at that time. He was appointed Naval [[Aide-de-Camp]] to [[Elizabeth II|the Queen]] on 7 July 1970.{{LondonGazette |issue=45168 |supp=yes |startpage=8853 |date=7 August 1970 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} [[File:HMS Albion.jpg|thumb|left|The aircraft carrier {{HMS|Albion|R07|6}} which Leach commanded in the early 1970s]] Leach became Assistant Chief of the Naval Staff (Policy) at the Ministry of Defence in April 1971, receiving promotion to [[rear admiral]] on 7 July 1971,{{LondonGazette |issue=45410 |supp=yes |startpage=6943 |date=28 June 1971 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} and then became Flag Officer First Flotilla in May 1974, with promotion to [[vice admiral]] on 6 July 1974.{{LondonGazette |issue=46363 |supp=yes |startpage=8525 |date=8 October 1974 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} He became [[Vice-Chief of the Defence Staff (United Kingdom)|Vice-Chief of the Defence Staff]] in January 1976, and having been appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] in the 1977 [[New Year Honours]],{{LondonGazette |issue=47102 |supp=yes |startpage=2 |date=30 December 1976 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} he was promoted to full [[admiral]] on 30 March 1977{{LondonGazette |issue=47184 |supp=yes |startpage=4281 |date=28 March 1977 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} on appointment as [[Commander-in-Chief Fleet]] and [[NATO]] Commander-in-Chief, Channel and Commander-in-Chief Eastern Atlantic. He was advanced to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] in the 1978 [[Birthday Honours]].{{LondonGazette |issue=47549 |supp=yes |startpage=6230 |date=2 June 1978 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} Leach was appointed [[First Sea Lord]] and Chief of Naval Staff on 6 July 1979{{LondonGazette |issue=47931 |supp=yes |startpage=10651 |date=20 August 1979 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} and in that role fiercely resisted naval cuts proposed by Defence Secretary [[John Nott]].{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2011/dec/30/thatcher-warned-defence-cuts-falklands |title=Thatcher warned of defence cuts dangers before Falklands war |newspaper=The Guardian |date=30 December 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} ===Falklands War=== {{see also|Falklands War}} [[File:The Falklands Conflict, April - June 1982 FKD2601.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Falkands War: Leach is second from the left]] On 31 March 1982, soon after the [[1982 invasion of the Falkland Islands|Argentine invasion of the Falklands]], Leach brushed aside serious doubts from the [[Secretary of State for Defence]] Sir [[John Nott]] and addressed the Prime Minister on the appropriate course of action.Hastings, pp. 85–86. The Chief of the Defence Staff at the time was on his way back from a foreign visit, and in addressing the Prime Minister, Leach effectively bypassed the Acting Chief of the Defence Staff. When he was asked if retaking the islands was possible, he replied "Yes we can recover the islands." He then added "and we must!" [[Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher]] replied "Why?" Leach exclaimed "''Because if we do not, or if we pussyfoot in our actions and do not achieve complete success, in another few months we shall be living in a different country whose word counts for little.''" Leach then explained how the task force would take shape and what ships would be involved: when asked about the lack of available aircraft carriers, Leach reassured the Prime Minister that the two small carriers available would suffice. Thatcher approved this and preparations were made to send a task force to set sail to retake the Falklands. On account of his determination, [[Andrew Marr]] referred to Leach as Thatcher's "Knight in Shining Gold Braid" in his documentary series ''[[Andrew Marr's History of Modern Britain|History of Modern Britain]]''. Upon his retirement in December 1982, Leach was promoted to [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]].{{LondonGazette |issue=49174 |supp=yes |startpage=15293 |date=22 November 1982 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} ==Later life== In retirement, Leach published his memoirs entitled ''Endure no Makeshifts''. He involved himself in several charitable organisations and acted as President of the Sea Cadet Association from 1983 to 1993. He was the Chairman of the Council of the [[King Edward VII's Hospital Sister Agnes|King Edward VII Hospital]] as well as being a chairman of the Royal Navy Club of 1765 & 1785 (United 1889).{{cite web |url=http://royalnavyclub.org/History.html |title=History |publisher=Royal Navy Club of 1765 & 1785 (United 1889) |accessdate=27 August 2012}} In 2004, it was announced that the new [[Navy Command Headquarters]] building of the Royal Navy at [[Whale Island, Hampshire|Whale Island]], [[Portsmouth]], was to be named the "Sir Henry Leach Building" in his honour.{{cite web |url=http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/69FD7584-CA23-431A-8064-FCB04C09F8C1/0/whaleisland.pdf |title=Henry Leach Building, New Naval HQ Whale Island |publisher=Ministry of Defence |work=Defence Estates |year=2004 |accessdate=27 August 2012 |format=PDF}} Leach lived at [[Wonston]] in [[Hampshire]]Heathcote, p. 153. and served as [[Deputy Lieutenant]] of [[Hampshire]].{{LondonGazette |issue=52975 |supp=yes |startpage=10910 |date=29 June 1992 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} His interests included shooting, fishing and gardening.{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2011/apr/26/admiral-of-the-fleet-sir-henry-leach-obituary |title=Obituary: Admiral of the Fleet Sir Henry Leach |publisher=The Guardian |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} He died on 26 April 2011 at the age of 87. A Service of Thanksgiving held in his honour was attended by representatives of the British Royal Family, including the current First Sea Lord [[Mark Stanhope|Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope]] in attendance on behalf of [[Elizabeth II|the Queen]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|the Duke of Edinburgh]].{{cite news |url=https://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=225393880823021 |title=Court Circular |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2012}} ==Family== Leach married Mary Jean McCall, daughter of Admiral [[Henry McCall|Sir Henry McCall]], in 1958. The Loss of the Prince of Wales and the Repulse |publisher=Penguin History |year=1979 |isbn=0-14-023469-1}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|IWUO-9TfPlg|Uncommon Knowledge Segment about Thatcher and Leach discussion on Falklands}} * [http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/80024622 Imperial War Museum Interview] {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box |title=[[Vice-Chief of the Defence Staff (United Kingdom)|Vice-Chief of the Defence Staff]] |before=[[Peter Le Cheminant|Sir Peter Le Cheminant]] |years=1975–1977 |after=[[Anthony Morton|Sir Anthony Morton]] }} |- {{succession box |title=[[Commander-in-Chief Fleet]] |before=[[John Treacher|Sir John Treacher]] |years=1977–1979 |after=[[James Eberle|Sir James Eberle]] }} |- {{succession box |title=[[First Sea Lord]] |before=[[Terence Lewin, Baron Lewin|Sir Terence Lewin]] |years=1979–1982 |after=[[John Fieldhouse, Baron Fieldhouse|Sir John Fieldhouse]] }} {{s-end}} {{First Sea Lord}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leach, Henry}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:First Sea Lords]] [[Category:People educated at St Peter's Court]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals of the fleet]] [[Category:Royal Navy officers of World War II]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Falklands War]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Hampshire]]
